title: [ThirdParty] Create tooling and document an approach for publishing native extensions

milestone.title: MVP (vNext M4)
milestone.description:
This "MVP" milestone tracks implementation of as much of RN core without significant workarounds current XAML (which would require [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3)).

- vNext is the default template (with vCurrent available as a fallback for compat for existing apps)
- Native Modules ready to be developed
- Measured percentage of lean core API completion (specific target percentage TBD)
- Built on [WinUI 2.x](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/)

body:
One of the most compelling aspects of react-native is the rich open source ecosystem of native extensions. We should make it as easy as possible for developers to write and publish third party native extensions (i.e., view managers and native modules) for React Native. This tooling / documentation should cover:

1. Recommended approach for publishing native code (i.e., as source code or binary)
2. How / where to publish native code and associated JavaScript? (likely NPM, but any additional source for native code?)
3. CLI or .vsix to generate templates / scaffolding for native extensions (see [`react-native-create-library`](https://github.com/frostney/react-native-create-library/) to see an example of this for the C# repo).

title: Document View - Style API completion

milestone.title: MVP (vNext M4)
milestone.description:
This "MVP" milestone tracks implementation of as much of RN core without significant workarounds current XAML (which would require [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3)).

- vNext is the default template (with vCurrent available as a fallback for compat for existing apps)
- Native Modules ready to be developed
- Measured percentage of lean core API completion (specific target percentage TBD)
- Built on [WinUI 2.x](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/)

body:
This is a placeholder issue to validate and implement (if not already supported) the remaining [Style props](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/0.59/view-style-props) on View:
- [x] opacity
- [x] backgroundColor
- [ ] borderRightColor #3077
- [ ] borderBottomColor #3077
- [ ] borderBottomEndRadius #3074
- [ ] borderBottomLeftRadius #3074
- [ ] borderBottomRightRadius #3074
- [ ] borderBottomStartRadius #3074
- [x] borderBottomWidth
- [x] borderColor
- [ ] borderEndColor #3077
- [ ] borderLeftColor #3077
- [x] borderLeftWidth
- [ ] borderRadius #3074
- [x] borderRightWidth
- [ ] borderStartColor #3077
- [ ] borderStyle #3078
- [ ] borderTopColor #3077
- [ ] borderTopEndRadius #3074
- [ ] borderTopLeftRadius #3074
- [ ] borderTopRightRadius #3074
- [ ] borderTopStartRadius #3074
- [x] borderTopWidth
- [x] borderWidth
- [ ] Shadow props #2800 

Not implementing
- [elevation](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/0.59/view-style-props#elevation)
_(Android-only) Sets the elevation of a view, using Android's underlying elevation API. This adds a drop shadow to the item and affects z-order for overlapping views. Only supported on Android 5.0+, has no effect on earlier versions._

title: Document Image API completion

milestone.title: MVP (vNext M4)
milestone.description:
This "MVP" milestone tracks implementation of as much of RN core without significant workarounds current XAML (which would require [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3)).

- vNext is the default template (with vCurrent available as a fallback for compat for existing apps)
- Native Modules ready to be developed
- Measured percentage of lean core API completion (specific target percentage TBD)
- Built on [WinUI 2.x](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/)

body:
The following unchecked properties are needed to complete the **Image** control integration into RNWCPP. ## P1 - [x] [**resizeMode - partial**](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/image#resizemode) Partially supported by Image. This guy is an Enum: -cover: Maps to Image.Stretch.UniformToFill -contain: Maps to Image.Stretch.Uniform -stretch: Maps to Image.Stretch.Fill -repeat: Not directly supported by Image. Would need to manually repeat, either by creating multiple XAML elements (eg a Grid of Images), or by dropping down to Composition (say, by using XCBB and creating a tiling Composition EffectBrush with a LoadedImageSurface as the input) -center: Not directly supported by Image. Would need to manually center/scale to fit, either in XAML (say, by computing a Brush transform) or by dropping down to Composition (similar to repeat) - [x] **onError** Maps to Image.ImageFailed - [x] **onLoadEnd** Not directly supported by Image, hook up to Image.ImageOpened/ImageFailed - [x] **onLoadStart** Not directly supported by Image, hook up underlying BitmapImage.DownloadProgress ## P2 - [ ] **blurRadius** #2631 Not directly supported by Image element. Would need to drop down the Composition for this. One possible proposal (using RS2 APIs): -Create a XamlCompositionBrushBbase and use this to fill the background of a Panel (eg Canvas) -The XCBB would create a Composition EffectBrush for the blur, and a LoadedImageSurface as the input. - [ ] [**defaultSource**](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/image#defaultsource) #2632 *A static image to display while loading the image source.* Not directly supported by Image. Would need to manually load/display this, similar to loadingIndicatorSource. - [ ] **loadingIndicatorSource** #2633 *Similarly to source, this property represents the resource used to render the loading indicator for the image, displayed until image is ready to be displayed, typically after when it got downloaded from network.* Not directly supported by Image. Would need to manually load/display the loading indicator image and switch to the real image when it's ready. There is likely open-source code for this that could be borrowed. - [ ] **fadeDuration** #2634 ## P3 - [ ] **progressiveRenderingEnabled** #2635 *Typically Android only. When true, enables progressive jpeg streaming. [See here](https://frescolib.org/docs/progressive-jpegs.html).* Not supported by XAML. Would need to do the decoding ourselves and render ourselves. - [ ] **overflow** #2636 https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/layout-props#overflow ## Already Completed - [x] **source** - [x] **onLayout** - [x] **onLoad** | Future | |:--| |
  • resizeMethod *Android Only*
  • accessible *iOS Only*
  • capInsets *iOS Only*
  • onPartialLoad *iOS Only*
  • onProgress *iOS Only*
|

title: Document ScrollView API completion

milestone.title: MVP (vNext M4)
milestone.description:
This "MVP" milestone tracks implementation of as much of RN core without significant workarounds current XAML (which would require [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3)).

- vNext is the default template (with vCurrent available as a fallback for compat for existing apps)
- Native Modules ready to be developed
- Measured percentage of lean core API completion (specific target percentage TBD)
- Built on [WinUI 2.x](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/)

body:
The following unchecked properties are needed to complete the **ScrollView** control integration into RNWCPP. ## P1 - [x] [**snapToInterval**](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/scrollview#snaptointerval) *When set, causes the scroll view to stop at multiples of the value of ```snapToInterval```.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Can be implemented as snap points (Win 8) on the child of the ScrollViewer. - [x] [**snapToOffsets**](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/scrollview#snaptooffsets) *When set, causes the scroll view to stop at the defined offsets.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Can be implemented as snap points (Win 8) on the child of the ScrollViewer. - [ ] **snapToStart** #3065 *Use in conjunction with ```snapToOffsets```. By default, the beginning of the list counts as a snap offset. Set ```snapToStart``` to false to disable this behavior and allow the list to scroll freely between its start and the first ```snapToOffsets``` offset. The default value is true.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Can be implemented in conjunction with adding snap points (Win 8) to the child of the ScrollViewer. - [ ] **snapToEnd** #3066 *Use in conjuction with ```snapToOffsets```. By default, the end of the list counts as a snap offset. Set ```snapToEnd``` to false to disable this behavior and allow the list to scroll freely between its end and the last ```snapToOffsets``` offset. The default value is true.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Can be implemented in conjunction with adding snap points (Win 8) to the child of the ScrollViewer. - [x] [**snapToAlignment**](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/scrollview#snaptoalignment) *When ```snapToInterval``` is set, ```snapToAlignment``` will define the relationship of the snapping to the scroll view.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Can be implemented in conjunction with adding snap points (Win 8) to the child of the ScrollViewer. - [ ] **removeClippedSubviews** #3067 *Experimental: When true, offscreen child views (whose overflow value is hidden) are removed from their native backing superview when offscreen. This can improve scrolling performance on long lists. The default value is true.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Seems difficult. Needs deep dive. - [ ] [**keyboardDismissMode**](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/scrollview#keyboarddismissmode) #3068 *Determines whether the keyboard gets dismissed in response to a drag.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Mobile-specific. Could be difficult, needs deep dive. - [x] **scrollEnabled** *When false, the view cannot be scrolled via touch interaction. The default value is true. Note that the view can always be scrolled by calling ```scrollTo```.* Maps to ScrollViewer.VerticalScrollMode/HorizontalScrollMode (Win 8) - [x] **showsHorizontalScrollIndicator** *When true, shows a horizontal scroll indicator. The default value is true.* Maps to ScrollViewer.HorizontalScrollBarVisibility (Win 8) - [x] **showsVerticalScrollIndicator** *When true, shows a vertical scroll indicator. The default value is true.* Maps to ScrollViewer.VerticalScrollBarVisibility (Win 8) ## P2 - [ ] **refreshControl** #3069 *A RefreshControl component, used to provide pull-to-refresh functionality for the ScrollView. Only works for vertical ScrollViews (```horizontal``` prop must be ```false```).* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Could maybe use RefreshContainer from MUX (RS4), or drop down to InteractionTracker (RS1) and build one from scratch. - [x] **onMomentumScrollBegin** *Called when the momentum scroll starts (scroll which occurs as the ScrollView glides to a stop).* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Could hook up to ViewChanging and look at ScrollViewerChangingEventArgs.IsInertial. - [x] **onMomentumScrollEnd** *Called when the momentum scroll ends (scroll which occurs as the ScrollView glides to a stop).* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Could hook up to ViewChanging/ViewChanged and look at ScrollViewerChangingEventArgs.IsInertial. - [ ] **stickyHeaderIndices** #3070 *An array of child indices determining which children get docked to the top of the screen when scrolling. For example, passing ```stickyHeaderIndices={[0]}``` will cause the first child to be fixed to the top of the scroll view. This property is not supported in conjunction with ```horizontal={true}```.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Seems difficult. Needs deep dive. ## P3 - [ ] [**decelerationRate**](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/scrollview#decelerationrate) #3071 *A floating-point number that determines how quickly the scroll view decelerates after the user lifts their finger.* Not supported by ScrollViewer. - [ ] **pagingEnabled** #3072 *When true, the scroll view stops on multiples of the scroll view's size when scrolling. This can be used for horizontal pagination. The default value is false.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Can be implemented by adding snap points (Win 8) to the child of the ScrollViewer - [ ] [**keyboardShouldPersistTaps**](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/scrollview#keyboardshouldpersisttaps) #3073 *Determines when the keyboard should stay visible after a tap.* Not directly supported by ScrollViewer. Mobile-specific. Could be difficult, needs deep dive. ## Already Completed - [x] **horizontal** - [x] **onScroll** - [x] **onScrollBeginDrag** - [x] **onScrollEndDrag** - [x] **onContentSizeChange** - [x] **contentContainerStyle** | Future| |:--| |
  • alwaysBounceVertical *iOS Only*
  • endfillColor *Android Only*
  • overScrollMode *Android Only*
  • scrollPerfTag *Android Only*
  • alwaysBounceHorizontal *iOS Only*
  • automactiallyAdjustcontentInsets *iOS Only*
  • bounces *iOS Only*
  • bouncesZoom *iOS Only*
  • canCancelContentTouches *iOS Only*
  • centerContent *iOS Only*
  • contentInset *iOS Only*
  • contentInsetAdjustmentBehavior *iOS Only*
  • contentOffset *iOS Only*
  • directionalLockEnabled *iOS Only*
  • indicatorStyle *iOS Only*
  • maximumZoomScale *iOS Only*
  • minimumZoomScale *iOS Only*
  • pinchGestureEnabled *iOS Only*
  • scrollEventThrottle *iOS Only*
  • scrollIndicatorInsets *iOS Only*
  • scrollsToTop *iOS Only*
  • zoomScale *iOS Only*
  • nestedScrollEnabled *Android Only*
|

title: Document TextInput API completion

milestone.title: MVP (vNext M4)
milestone.description:
This "MVP" milestone tracks implementation of as much of RN core without significant workarounds current XAML (which would require [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3)).

- vNext is the default template (with vCurrent available as a fallback for compat for existing apps)
- Native Modules ready to be developed
- Measured percentage of lean core API completion (specific target percentage TBD)
- Built on [WinUI 2.x](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/)

body:
The following unchecked properties are needed to complete the **TextInput** control integration into RNWCPP. ## P1 - [x] **autoFocus** ## P2 - [ ] **secureTextEntry** #3081 Not directly supported by TextBox. PasswordBox has this functionality. Can we hot-swap between TextBox/PasswordBox? - [ ] **keyboardType** #3080 Maps to TextBox.InputScope (Win8/Win8.1) - [ ] **autoComplete** #3079 Maps to TextBox.IsSpellCheckEnabled (Win8) ## P3 - [ ] **contextMenuHidden** #3088 Not supported by XAML - [ ] **caretHidden** #3087 Not supported by TextBox. Is supported by RichEditBox.TextDocument.CaretType. We could maybe hack this to work in TextBox by using VisualTreeHelper. - [ ] **autoCorrect** #3086 - [ ] **autoCapitalize** #3085 Incomplete support in XAML. This guy is an enum: -characters: Maps to TextBox.CharacterCasing.Upper (RS3) -words: Not supported -sentences: Not directly supported. TextBox.IsSpellCheckEnabled (Win8) turns on auto-capitalizing first word in a sentence (which maps to autoCapitalize.sentences) but this also turns on spell-checking. Also, MikeHill says: Some of the auto capitalization functionality in TextBox is behind the InputScope API. -none: Supported by default - [ ] **blurOnSubmit** #3084 Not supported in XAML - [ ] **onSubmitEditing** #3083 Needs more investigation. Mobile specific feature, is this needed? - [ ] **returnKeyType** #3082 Needs more investigation. Mobile specific feature, is this needed? ## Already Completed - [x] **clearTextOnFocus** - [x] **defaultValue** - [x] **editable** - [x] **maxLength** - [x] **multiline** - [x] **onBlur** - [x] **onChange** - [x] **onChangeText** - [x] **onContentSizeChange** - [x] **onEndEditing** - [x] **onFocus** - [x] **onKeyPress** - [x] **onLayout** - [x] **onScroll** - [x] **onSelectionChange** - [x] **selection** - [x] **selectionColor** - [x] **selectTextOnFocus** - [x] **value** - [x] **allowFontScaling** Maps to Control.IsTextScaleFactorEnabled (Phone 8.1) - [x] **placeholder** - [x] **placeholderTextColor** | Future| |:--| |
  • clearButtonMode *iOS Only*
  • dataDetectorTypes *iOS Only*
  • disabledFullscreenUI *Android Only*
  • enablesReturnKeyAtuomatically *iOS Only*
  • inlineImageLeft *Android Only*
  • inlineImagePadding *Android Only*
  • keyboardAppearance *iOS Only*
  • maxFontSizeMultiplier *iOS Only*
  • numberOfLines *Android Only*
  • returnKeyLabel *Android Only*
  • scrollEnabled *iOS Only*
  • selectionState *iOS Only*
  • spellCheck *iOS Only*
  • textContentType *iOS Only*
  • textBreakStrategy *Android Only*
  • underlineColorAndroid *Android Only*
|

title: Need to whitelist pngs/gifs submitted to docs directory
body: PRs to add docs need not run the CI loop. This is mostly done now, except gifs/pngs/jpeg files added to docs folders also need to be whitelisted to not trigger build pipeline.

title: How to create a react-native-window app for WPF platform?
body:
I'd like to create a demo application for WPF platform and didn't find any guideline for it, could you provide the detail steps?

Regards

title: BackHandler connection to app-level software "Back button"
body:
### Environment

1. `react-native -v`: 0.55.4
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`: 0.2.8
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`: 0.55.0-rc.0
4. `node -v`: v10.13.0
5. `npm -v`: 6.4.1
6. `yarn --version` 1.12.3

Then, specify:

- Target Platform: UWP

- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.14393

- Target Device(s): Desktop

- Development Operating System: Windows 10

- Visual Studio Version: 2017

- Build Configuration: All

### Steps to Reproduce

componentDidMount() {
    BackHandler.addEventListener("hardwareBackPress", this.handleBackPress);
}

### Expected Behavior

BackHandler gets invoked on a hardware or software button press

### Actual Behavior

This works for the hardware button, but there is no easy/apparent way to hook this up to the software buttons. 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/uwp/design/basics/navigation-history-and-backwards-navigation

is quite detailed on handling this, but it's unclear how that would fit the RN Windows BackHandler story. There is apparently two ways of doing this:

 - an older, no-longer-recommended app-level way, via https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/uwp/api/windows.ui.core.systemnavigationmanager.appviewbackbuttonvisibility#Windows_UI_Core_SystemNavigationManager_AppViewBackButtonVisibility
- the current recommendation of each page/app doing it separately

In either case, I would expect this to be handled (even if optionally) on the framework level, as it is on Android, so if there were subscribers to backhandler (BackHandler.addEventListener...) the Back arrow would show. I don't really care if that's done via AppViewBackButton or some other means, what I want to avoid is extensive (Windows-only) plumbing that enables this (as then it gets even more complicated, with RTL considerations to boot).

My current workaround is to wrap BackHandler and toggle AppViewBackButtonVisibility if I have subscribers, but as said, I'd like to avoid per-platform components especially if there is a precedent in RN proper. If this *is* in line with the RNW team, I'm happy to upstream.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/822934/48431249-7c04c780-e72e-11e8-80cd-63eb20372141.png)

title: stucks at "fetching javascript bundle" dialog
body:
### Environment


1. `react-native -v`: 0.57.1
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`: rnpm-plugin-windows@0.2.8
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`:
4. `node -v`: 8.11.3
5. `npm -v`: 5,6
6. `yarn --version` 1.9.4

Then, specify:

- Target Platform: UWP

- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.14393

- Target Device(s): Mobile Emulator

- Development Operating System: Windows 10

- Visual Studio Version: 2017

- Build Configuration: Debug

(Write your steps here:)

1. follow instructions : https://github.com/Microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/master/docs/GettingStarted.md
2. alter DevServerHelper.cs line :
```
private const string DeviceLocalhost = "192.168.0.110:8081";
```
3. run 
```
react-native start --host 192.168.0.110 --port 8081
```
4. run from visual studio 2017 solution file targeting device emulator

### Expected Behavior

React native welcome screen

### Actual Behavior

Stuck on "fetching javascript bundle " dialog

Console shows :
```
 BUNDLE  [windows, dev] ./index.js  100.0% (541/541), done.

 BUNDLE  [windows, dev] ./index.js  100.0% (541/541)192.168.0.110 - - [25/Sep/2018:08:42:13 +0000] "GET /index.bundle?platform=windows&dev=true&hot=false HTTP/1.1" 200 2961578 "-" "-"
```
so i guess emulator can access metro bundler host but still it freezes at "fetching" dialog.

I've tried "local machine" target and it works as expected.

title: RN4W current needs to support newest CLI
body:
The current version of RN4W still uses the legacy rnpm plugin way of extending the react-native cli.  This method has been deprecated for a while, but as of [this PR](https://github.com/react-native-community/cli/pull/790) it is no longer supported by the CLI.

I believe that this means that all the CLI commands (things like run-windows) will no longer work on the current version.

title: Drop Shadow support for View, Text, Image, and more

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
# Proposal: Drop Shadow support for View, Text, Image, and more
Implement support for ViewStyle.shadow* and TextStyle.textShadow* for View, Text, and Image.

## Summary
Tasks

1. A C++/winrt port of `DropShadowPanel`, to be called `ShadowedContentControl` will be used for shadows cast from all XAML-based components.
2. Implement TextStyle.textShadow* support
3. Implement ViewStyle.shadow* support for <View> ViewStyle.border* and ViewStyle.backgroundColor props
4. Implement ViewStyle.shadow* support for RN <Image>, ImageViewManager
5. Optionally, extend and share `ShadowedContentControl` for reuse by third parties

## Motivation
React Native supports shadows for View, Text, and Image using the ViewStyle.shadow* and TextStyle.textShadow* props. Android and iOS both support these properties (though with some notable differences), but support hasnt been implemented in react-native-windows vNext yet. The WPF RN project has support but a straight port to UWP isnt possible due to differences in shadow APIs available between WPF and UWP + XAML + Composition.

Shadows will improve application visuals and usability. In addition to aiding visualization of the application's information hierarchy and drawing attention to UX of interest, drop shadows can also be used to enhance readability of text against low-contrast or "busy" background content such as a photograph. A shadow without vertical or horizontal offsets can also be used to create a "glow" effect, used for similar design and usability goals.

## Basic example
```
<View>
        <Text style={{shadowColor: "red", shadowRadius: 2, shadowOpacity: 1, shadowOffset: {width: 1, height: 1}}}>This is text using ViewStyle.shadow* props</Text>
        <Text style={{textShadowColor: 'red', textShadowRadius: 2, textShadowOffset: {width: 1, height: 1}}}>This is text using TextStyle.textShadow* props</Text>

        <Image source={{uri: 'https://cdn.freebiesupply.com/logos/large/2x/disney-1-logo-png-transparent.png'}} style={{width: 200, height: 200, shadowColor: "red", shadowRadius: 2, shadowOpacity: 1, shadowOffset: {width: 1, height: 1}}} />

        <View style={{width: 300, height: 50, backgroundColor: "blue", shadowColor: "red", shadowRadius: 2, shadowOpacity: 1, shadowOffset: {width: 1, height: 1}, marginBottom: 20}} />

        <View style={{width: 300, height: 250, borderColor: "blue", borderWidth: 5, borderRadius: 20, borderStyle: 'dotted', shadowColor: "red", shadowRadius: 2, shadowOpacity: 1, shadowOffset: {width: 1, height: 1}}}>
          <Text>Shadow on a view with dotted border. Child elements (text and image) inherit ViewStyle.shadow* props</Text>
          <Image source={{uri: 'https://cdn.freebiesupply.com/logos/large/2x/disney-1-logo-png-transparent.png'}} style={{width: 200, height: 200}} />
        </View>
</View>
```

![RN DropShadow Android and iOS](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2568938/61496628-a10ea180-a971-11e9-807f-66f6e5a82c1a.PNG)

## Open Questions
### View shadows, iOS, Android, and staging work
iOS and Android's support for shadows on <View> elements differs in one important way: on iOS all the children of the view also get the same drop shadow visuals applied to them. On android, the view's shadow only affects the view's border and background visuals, not all the children too. This can be seen in the screenshot above.

Android's model seems ideal because it allows for the most flexibility. On iOS, if you want a View's border to have shadow visuals, but you don't want the children to, then you have to put the children in another superimposed view. On Android, you simply set the shadow props on all the elements you want to have shadows. Similarly, in the event where child <Text> and a parent <View> should both have shadows, on Android you're able to use the specialized textShadow props on the Text, which visually look better than iOS's inherited ViewStyle.shadow* visuals (see first two Text shadows in screenshot above).

However, I can guess how iOS' behavior came about. If we were to implement ShadowedContentControl using the "SoftwareBitmap -> CompositionBrush -> AlphaMask" technique, the shadow visuals would apply not only to the View itself, but also all children. 

With that background information out of the way, we can discuss work staging. Rewriting ViewViewManager to use Composition border rendering instead of a XAML <Border> control would be a substantial task. The fastest path to supporting View shadows is to use the "SoftwareBitmap -> CompositionBrush -> AlphaMask" technique. However, this would mean children inherit shadows, like iOS. It also would be inferior performance-wise. Luckily, shadows are opt-in so it's pay-for-play.

Long-term there seems to be agreement on adopting Composition for a plethora of benefits (smaller XAML tree, improved performance, support for ViewStyle.borderStyle "dotted" and "dashed", etc.), but ShadowedContentControl + SoftwareBitmap -> CompositionBrush -> AlphaMask could help us get to basic drop shadow support faster. The short-term work also wouldn't go wasted, because it accrues towards making ShadowedContentControl work with arbitrary XAML types, useful for third parties wanting shadows for their own custom NativeComponents written wrapping XAML components.

### RN Glyph / NativeComponent "PLYIcon"
IconViewManager is currently implemented using Glyph, not a XAML <TextBlock>. We would like shadow support for these elements too, but I'm not sure which implementation would be preferred. Some possibilities:
a. If ShadowedContentContainer has support for arbitrary XAML content via the SoftwareBitmap -> CompositionBrush -> AlphaMask approach, Glyph could be wrapped in a ShadowedContentContainer.
b. IconViewManager could be rewritten to use <TextBlock> instead of Glyph. The TextBlock could then be wrapped using ShadowedContentContainer.
c. IconViewMangager could be rewritten to be drawn using Composition with DropShadow.
d. Alternatively, our client could migrate from Glyph-based icons to using <Image> or <Text> components.

### Popup/Flyout and Context Menu
Shadows are also of interest for these components but I haven't investigated enough to include anything along with this proposal.

title: Build react-native-win32.dll will Office build tools
body:
I'm posting this change for early feedback; I do not intend to submit this in its current state. Currently, it only consists of a PS script that installs the Office build tools, patches them up, emits build .props and .targets to use the Office build tools, and creates a PS script that invokes msbuild with properties that cause the build props and targets to be loaded.

In the current state, react-native-win32.dll does get built and the respective UTs and integration tests succeed.

Work still required on top of what's presented here includes:
- Creation of ADO .yaml files to govern ADO pipelines
- Call the PS install script from the .yamls - or, more likely, distribute the contents of the PS install script across several .yaml files
- figure out how to access the Office-internal feed from the ADO agent pool
- add validation steps to ensure we're actually building with the Office tools/did not regress to build with standard tools
- probably switch from PS package management cmdlets to nuget.exe calls to avoid "DLL hell" due to differing dependency resolution

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/3402)

title: "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\BuildTools\MSBuild\Microsoft\WindowsXaml\v15.0\Microsoft.Windows.UI.Xaml.Cpp.targets" was not found.
body:

```
v11.2.0

D:\code\react-native\windowsQuickstart>npm -v
6.4.1
D:\code\react-native\windowsQuickstart>yarn --version
1.12.1
```

Then, specify:

<!-- (What framework version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.14393, 10.0.10586, 10.0.10240, etc. (UWP), .NET 4.6.1, .NET 4.5, etc. (WPF) -->

<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Mobile (ARM), Mobile Emulator, Xbox, Hololens) -->

<!-- Which operating system are you using? Specify macOS, Windows, or Linux, along with specific release versions -->

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2017 -->

<!-- Which build configuration are you running? Choose from Debug, DebugBundle, Release, ReleaseBundle -->
- Build Configuration:

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
  How would you describe your issue to someone who doesnt know you or your project?
  Try to write a sequence of steps that anybody can repeat to see the issue.
  Be specific! If the bug cannot be reproduced, your issue may be closed.
-->
I followed the instruction on https://github.com/Microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/master/docs/GettingStarted.md, but I got the following error when I run `react-native run-windows`.
```

D:\code\react-native\windowsQuickstart> react-native run-windows
Restoring NuGet packages
Building D:/code/react-native/windowsQuickstart/windows/windowsQuickstart.sln
Found MSBuild v15.0 at C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\BuildTools\MSBuild\15.0\Bin

Build configuration: Debug

Building the projects in this solution one at a time. To enable parallel build, please add the "/m" switch.
C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\BuildTools\Common7\IDE\VC\VCTargets\Microsoft.CppCommon.targets(2128,3): error MSB4019: The imported proj
ect "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\BuildTools\MSBuild\Microsoft\WindowsXaml\v15.0\Microsoft.Windows.UI.Xaml.Cpp.targets" was not found.
 Confirm that the path in the <Import> declaration is correct, and that the file exists on disk. [D:\code\react-native\windowsQuickstart\node_modules\react-n
ative-windows\Yoga\csharp\Yoga\Yoga.Universal.vcxproj]
Build failed with message Error: Command failed: "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\BuildTools\MSBuild\15.0\Bin\msbuild.exe" "D:/code/react-native/windowsQuickstart/windows/windowsQuickstart.sln" /clp:NoSummary;NoItemAndPropertyList;Verbosity=quiet /nologo /p:Configuration=Debug /p:Platform=x86 /p:AppxBundle=Never /p:PlatformToolset=v141 /p:VisualStudioVersion=15.0. Check your build configuration.

```

I also have tried the tips mentioned https://github.com/Microsoft/testfx/issues/314, here are some snapshot of my environment.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2276718/49494315-3acd8680-f89a-11e8-96e1-9f0f1019e620.png)

### Expected Behavior

  How did you expect your project to behave?
  Its fine if youre not sure your understanding is correct.

-->

title: Proposal for better developer user experience via VM or docker

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
It took hours or days for new customer to setup dev environment successfully to start and evaluate react-native-windows.

The best solution is expo, but I didn't see it supports windows in the next 6 months. We may go with other options: VM and docker.

There is a very good example that customer could finish 'Pre-Configured environments in the cloud for Data Science and AI Development' in less than 15 minutes by [data-science-virtual-machines](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/virtual-machines/data-science-virtual-machines/)

[azure-pipelines-image-generation](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-image-generation) provides procedures and pipeline to build the virtual machine automatically, and it's possible for us to ship VM of react native windows dev enviroment monthly or weekly.

I don't know if docker supports for UWP apps or not, it's also worth to investigate if customer can recover a react native windows dev enviroment by docker.

title: Style inheritance for Text components
body:
React Native for iOS and Android both have the concept of style inheritance for Text subtrees. However, on Windows this is (currently) not the case.

Example:
```
<Text style={{color: 'red'}}>
    I am red
    <Text>
        I should be red by inheritance
    </Text>
</Text>
```

title: Add pictures for the NativeAnimatedModule write up
body: ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/3429)

title: Support starting a headless react instance
body:
This is what I believe to be the minimum set of changes to allow starting a react instance with no window. This allows running UWP background tasks written in javascript.

This explains how the android version of this api works.
https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/0.60/headless-js-android

Note, this does not include a native module for HeadlessJsTaskSupport.
My thoughts are that it is a trivial interface to implement when you can make assumptions about your specific app. But might be difficult to expose something useful in the platform.

https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/91f139b94118fe8db29728ea8ad855fc4a13f743/Libraries/ReactNative/NativeHeadlessJsTaskSupport.js

The playground now has an example that shows how a react instance can be started with an in-process background task, and transferred to run in the foreground.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/3365)

title: Basic slider implementation
body:
The native animated test page for RNTester requires a slider implementation.  This change gets the page off the floor, but doesn't provide very much functionality for the slider control.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/3381)

title: Remove unicode conversion functions from def files.
body: Currently, both react-native-win32.dll and react.uwp.dll export Unicode conversion functions. This is due to older versions of react native's relying on non-standard Unicode conversions. The non-standard behavior has been removed, and we should remove those functions from the dll exports.
